page.title: 10 ASH SCHOOL HISTORY
page.content: John Prowde in his will in 1626 ordered a charity school to be built in land adjoining the church,but it was never completed and children continued to be educated in the church.In 1721 Gervase Cartwright died and left 50 pounds p/a for the teaching of 50 poor children 25 boys and 25 girls. In 1841 Thomas Kelsey built the infant school in Chequer Lane at his own expense in memory of his 9 year old daughter Elizabeth who died,it was for children aged 3-8 years.In 1819 Mrs Elizabeth Godfrey gave 1000 pounds for the junior school to be built in The Street.After 1944 Education Act,the senior children were moved to Sandwich Central School and the two junior schools became Cartwright Junior Mixed Charity School The present school was opened by the Archbishop of Canterbury in 1964 and is called Cartwright & Kelsey CEP School.
